biography.label: Biography
biography.value:
Cleric Captain Helga Schlamme is a hero amongst the Order of the Fiery Heart and the last living descendant of Sigune Schlamme – a hero who gave her life protecting Magnus the Pious while he dueled Asavar Kul. Wearing her full enchanted battle armour, polished to perfection, and her spotless white livery with striking Fiery Heart blazon, she is the embodiment of piety and Imperial wrath. This is especially true in the wars against the Greenskins, for whom she has particular enmity. When she isn’t guarding the Grand Theogonist, Helga can be found leading the charge in campaigns against Orcs or Goblins, smashing them to ash with the same fiery Comet Hammer her ancestor wielded centuries prior. 

Helga grew up in a village outside Nuln with stories from her father about her family’s heritage – tales of Sigune, and the many priests, warrior priests and templars in the Schlamme line that followed in her footsteps. Her father was a High Priest of Sigmar himself, and hoped one day to conclude his service to Sigmar as a scribe in favor of serving with sword in hand. Fate can be cruel, sadly. The temple Helga’s family stayed in was raided by Orcs led by a massive armour-clad Black Orc – nearly 9 feet tall – and 10 year-old Helga was forced to watch from the temple’s roof as her family fought to the bitter end. When the dust settled, she was alone. She was later rescued by a road warden patrol, who came to investigate the smoke coming from the temple grounds, and was adopted as a Page by the Order – in honor of her family’s legacy. 

Two decades later, and she managed to climb the ranks of the Order. She excelled as both a knight and priestess, even training under the warrior priests who accompany the Order. Many joked she was Sigune reincarnated. Once she earned the right to wield the Comet Hammer, she personally hunted down and smashed to cinders the Black Orc, his second in command and his entire tribe. She wears the skulls of the two Orcs over her pauldrons to this day.

trappings: Reckoning Great Hammer or Comet Flail with Lamp Oil
Light Warhorse with Saddle and Tack

description.value: You are watched over by one of the Gods and can empower simple prayers. You can now deploy the Blessings of your deity as listed in @UUID[JournalEntry.NcH9OhleJFfaUdon]{Religion and Belief}. Under normal circumstances, you may only ever know one Divine Lore for the Bless Talent.

You can blend in socially with the chosen group so long as you are dressed and acting appropriately. Example social groups for this Talent are: Criminals, Cultists, Guilders, Nobles, Scholars, Servants, and Soldiers. If you do not have the Talent, those with it will note your discomfort in the unfamiliar environment. This is primarily a matter for roleplaying, but may confer a bonus to Fellowship Tests at the GM’s discretion.
You are one of the rare literate individuals in the Old World. You are assumed to be able to read and write (if appropriate) all of the Languages you can speak.
You are the epitome of determination and resolve. Add your level in Strong Minded to your maximum Resolve pool.

Your rousing words and pleas can turn the tide of a battle. Refer to the following table to see how many people you can now inﬂuence with your Leadership Skill when at war.

 

Talent Taken

Number of soldiers inﬂuenced

1

As normal × 5

2

As normal × 10

3

 As normal × 20

4

 As normal × 50

5

 As normal × 100

6

 As normal × 200

7

 As normal × 500

8

 As normal × 1000

9

 All who can hear your inspiring voice

You are blessed by one of the Gods and can empower one of your Cult’s Miracles. Further, you may purchase extra miracles for 100 XP per miracle you currently know. So, if you already know 3 miracles, your next miracle costs 300 XP to purchase. Full rules for learning new miracles are provided in @UUID[JournalEntry.NcH9OhleJFfaUdon]{Religion and Belief}. Under normal circumstances, you may not learn more than one Invoke (Divine Lore) Talent. Further, @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.mdPGZsn2396dEpOf]{Petty Magic} or @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.3O9clK7LGyuLTHPW]{Arcane Magic} Talents when you have the Invoke Talent. You can unlearn this Talent for 100 XP, but will lose all of your miracles if you do so, and will also garner the extreme disfavor of your God, with effects determined by your GM

You are an inquisitive soul who has travelled far and wide, learning all manner of local information. Add Lore (Local) to any Career you enter; if it is already in Career, you may purchase the Skill, both times — a different Specialty each time, such as Altdorf, Vorbergland, or Ubersreik — for 5 XP fewer per Advance.

tests.value: Any Lore Test concerning local detail

description.value: No matter how bad things get, you always seem to come back for more. You may attempt a Cool Test to remove a @Condition[Broken] Condition at the end of each of your Turns as well as at the end of the Round.

tests.value: Cool Tests to remove Broken Conditions

description.value: You are either brave enough or crazy enough that fear of certain enemies has become a distant memory. With a single Average (+20) Cool Test, you may ignore any Intimidate, Fear, or Terror effects from the specified enemy when encountered. Typical enemies include Beastmen, Greenskins, Outlaws, Vampires, Watchmen, and Witches.

tests.value: Cool to oppose your Enemy's Intimidate, Fear, and Terror

description.value: Your stern gaze and inspiring words motivate your soldiers to fight on to the end. All subordinates able to see you may add your level in War Leader to their SL in one Willpower Test per Round. This bonus does not stack.

You can blend in socially with the chosen group so long as you are dressed and acting appropriately. Example social groups for this Talent are: Criminals, Cultists, Guilders, Nobles, Scholars, Servants, and Soldiers. If you do not have the Talent, those with it will note your discomfort in the unfamiliar environment. This is primarily a matter for roleplaying, but may confer a bonus to Fellowship Tests at the GM’s discretion.
You gain a permanent +5 bonus to your starting Willpower Characteristic this does not count towards your Advances.

At the age of 10, a Priest of Morr called a Doomsayer took you aside to foretell your death in an incense-laden, coming-of-age ritual called the Dooming. In conjunction with your GM, come up with a suitable Dooming. Should your character die in a fashion that matches your Dooming, your next character gains a bonus of half the total XP your dead character accrued during play.

@Table[doom]

You are at home in the saddle in even the most difficult of circumstances, and know how to get the best out of your mount during conﬂict. Assuming you have the Ride skill, you can direct your mount to take an Action, not just a Move, without a Ride test.

You are an inquisitive soul who has travelled far and wide, learning all manner of local information. Add Lore (Local) to any Career you enter; if it is already in Career, you may purchase the Skill, both times — a different Specialty each time, such as Altdorf, Vorbergland, or Ubersreik — for 5 XP fewer per Advance.

tests.value: Any Lore Test concerning local detail

description.value: You are an inquisitive soul who has travelled far and wide, learning all manner of local information. Add Lore (Local) to any Career you enter; if it is already in Career, you may purchase the Skill, both times — a different Specialty each time, such as Altdorf, Vorbergland, or Ubersreik — for 5 XP fewer per Advance.

tests.value: Any Lore Test concerning local detail

description.value: You are skilled at using your shield to maneuver others in combat so you can take advantage of a desperate situation. When using a Shield to defend, you gain Advantage equal to the number of levels you have in Shieldsman if you lose the Opposed Test.

tests.value: Any Test to defend with a shield

description.value: You know how to hit hard! You deal your level of Strike Mighty Blow in extra Damage with melee weapons.
You know how to hit hard! You deal your level of Strike Mighty Blow in extra Damage with melee weapons.
You are the epitome of determination and resolve. Add your level in Strong Minded to your maximum Resolve pool.
You are the epitome of determination and resolve. Add your level in Strong Minded to your maximum Resolve pool.
You have a brawny physique, or are very used to carrying things. Increase the number of Encumbrance Points you can carry by your Sturdy level x 2
You have a brawny physique, or are very used to carrying things. Increase the number of Encumbrance Points you can carry by your Sturdy level x 2
You gain a permanent +5 bonus to your starting Weapon Skill Characteristic (doesn't count as Advances).
The creature is particularly sharp-minded. It receives +20 Intelligence and +10 Initiative.

You are consumed with Hatred for the Target, which is normally a group of people or creatures, such as ‘Hochlanders’, ‘Bog Octopuses’, or ‘Slavers’. You will never socially interact with someone or something you hate in this manner. On encountering the object of your Hatred, you must attempt a Psychology Test. If failed, you are subject to Hatred. At the end of every subsequent Round, you may attempt another Psychology Test to bring the Hatred to an end. If you do or not, the effects of Hatred naturally come to an end when all members of the specified group in your line of sight are dead or gone, or you gain the Unconscious condition. While subject to Hatred, you must immediately attempt to destroy the hated group by the fastest and most deadly means possible. You gain a bonus of +1 SL on all combat Tests against the specified group, and are immune to Fear and Intimidate (but not Terror) caused by your hated foe.

The creature is a practiced leader. It receives a bonus of +10 to Fellowship and Willpower. Note: this Trait cannot be taken by creatures with the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.Item.AGcJl5rHjkyIQBPP]{Bestial} Trait.

god.value: Manann, Morr, Myrmidia, Sigmar, Ulric, Verena

description.value: Enemies must make an Average (+20) Willpower Test to attack your target as shame wells within for considering violence. If they fail, they must choose a different target, or a different Action

You call the power of Sigmar to smite the enemies of the Empire. A holy fire explodes from your body blasting outwards for Fellowship Bonus yards. All targets within range take 1d10 Wounds ignoring Toughness Bonus and APs. Targets with the Undead and Daemon Creature Traits also gain the Ablaze Condition. For every +2 SL, you may increase the area of effect by +Fellowship Bonus yards, or cause an extra +2 Damage to any Greenskins, Undead, or servants of the Ruinous Powers affected.

You invoke litanies to Sigmar, calling on him to smite his foes. A twin-tailed comet, blazing a trail of fire in its wake, plummets from the heavens to strike a point within Line of Sight and range. Everything within Fellowship Bonus yards of the point of impact suffers 1d10 + SL Damage, ignoring Toughness Bonus and Armor Points, and gains the @Condition[Ablaze] condition. The target location must be outdoors, and may only target those Sigmar would deem an enemy.

You chant benedictions of Sigmar’s might. If wielding a warhammer, it counts as Magical, deals +Fellowship Bonus Damage, and any target struck receives the @Condition[Ablaze] and @Condition[Prone] Conditions.

The origins of the Comet Hammer date as far back as the Great War against Chaos in 2304 IC. It was the main instrument of righteous punishment used by Cleric Captain Sigune Schlamme of the Order of the Fiery Heart, a former High Priestess of Sigmar. After falling in the Battle of Finuval Plain defending the Emperor, Magnus the Pious, Sigune was given a queen’s burial and her hammer has been passed down across Cleric Captains and Warrior Priest Captains of the Order ever since for the last two centuries. 

Weapon Type: Skull-Splitter Hammer. 

Ability: The hammer has the Lightweight Quality and was blessed by a priest of Sigmar, counting it as Magical. In the hands of a Blessed Sigmarite, the Comet Hammer may be thrown and treated as if it’s a Ranged (Throwing) weapon. The hammer has a Range of SBx3 yards, and the thrower gains a +30 bonus to Ballistic Skill Tests on such attacks with this weapon. The hammer returns to the thrower’s hand at the end of their Turn. 

The wielder of the Comet Hammer may invoke its fiery power by stating ‘By Sigmar’s Holy Light!’ erupting the Comet Hammer into white and orange flames—holy runes illuminating across the hammer’s cheek and face. The flame grants the same amount of light as a torch; moreover, it cannot be quenched, snuffed, or otherwise put out, even if it is fully submerged in water. If the wielder hits a flammable target with the Comet Hammer, either in melee or thrown, the target suffers one @Condition[Ablaze] Condition. Followers of Chaos and Undead gain +SL @Condition[Ablaze] Conditions.

The origins of the Comet Hammer date as far back as the Great War against Chaos in 2304 IC. It was the main instrument of righteous punishment used by Cleric Captain Sigune Schlamme of the Order of the Fiery Heart, a former High Priestess of Sigmar. After falling in the Battle of Finuval Plain defending the Emperor, Magnus the Pious, Sigune was given a queen’s burial and her hammer has been passed down across Cleric Captains and Warrior Priest Captains of the Order ever since for the last two centuries. 

Weapon Type: Skull-Splitter Hammer. 

Ability: The hammer has the Lightweight Quality and was blessed by a priest of Sigmar, counting it as Magical. In the hands of a Blessed Sigmarite, the Comet Hammer may be thrown and treated as if it’s a Ranged (Throwing) weapon. The hammer has a Range of SBx3 yards, and the thrower gains a +30 bonus to Ballistic Skill Tests on such attacks with this weapon. The hammer returns to the thrower’s hand at the end of their Turn. 

The wielder of the Comet Hammer may invoke its fiery power by stating ‘By Sigmar’s Holy Light!’ erupting the Comet Hammer into white and orange flames—holy runes illuminating across the hammer’s cheek and face. The flame grants the same amount of light as a torch; moreover, it cannot be quenched, snuffed, or otherwise put out, even if it is fully submerged in water. If the wielder hits a flammable target with the Comet Hammer, either in melee or thrown, the target suffers one @Condition[Ablaze] Condition. Followers of Chaos and Undead gain +SL @Condition[Ablaze] Conditions.

The wielder of this tome may use its power to cast a single Miracle that causes Damage, including Miracles that affect weapons. The wielder does not need to make a Pray Test. The tome can only be used once every 24-hour period.

Battle Tomes are rare in the Empire, and to the frustration of priests who know better, all are inevitably called Tomes of ‘Sigmar’ or ‘Ulric’ as the two gods are known to have the highest number of Warrior Priests who make use of these artifacts.

This amulet is a wide carving of deep-green stone in the shape of a god’s patron animal. It may be affixed to a metal breastplate, a belt buckle or worn on a necklace. It is reputed these artefacts are blessed by Arch Lectors. A Jade Amulet grants its wearer the Regenerate Creature Trait.

You call on Ulric to make manifest his disdain for the weak, the cowardly and the deceitful. The target suffers [[/r 1d10]] wounds ignoring Toughness Bonus and Armor Points. If the GM rules that the target is neither weak, cowardly, or deceitful, you suffer the effects instead.

Made from star-metal and engraved with ancient prayers of vengeance and retribution, these exceptionally rare rings are worn by powerful priests devoted to wiping out the enemies of mankind and its allies. When casting a Damaging Miracle the wearer may deal +3 bonus Damage. A Ring of Wrath must be charged with a Challenging (+0) Pray Test after every use in order to be used again.

The Armour of Righteous Fury is a suit of armour (usually leather) that was often used by high ranking Witch Hunters for centuries, although its creation secrets have since been discovered and sold across the Old World. Opulent and well-known, its powers are twofold. The armour is inlaid with sigils that increase the wearer’s Toughness Bonus by +1 for the purposes of Damage reduction. In addition, it increases the wearer’s Movement Attribute by +1 and during combat you may immediately spend an Advantage to make an extra attack. Full suit required.
You pray to Sigmar for protection and he rewards you with a nimbus of holy, fiery power to protect you from harm. You gain +2 AP on all locations.

items.name: Healing Hand of the God Emperor

description.value: Your earnest prayers appeal to Sigmar to grant the target renewed strength and vigor—to best aid in protecting the Empire and mankind. Your touch restores [[/r 1d10]] Wounds for the target. If the target is a citizen of the Empire or Dwarf, they receive your Fellowship Bonus in additional Wounds.

effects.name: Healing Hand of the God Emperor

scriptData.label: Healing Hand

description.value: You call on Sigmar to protect those close to you from the fell inﬂuence of Chaos. Any spells that target anyone or anywhere within Fellowship Bonus yards suffer a penalty of –20 to Language (Magick) Tests, in addition to any other penalties. For every +2 SL, you may increase the area of effect by your Fellowship Bonus in yards.
